text: since you and I you know both teach you
go you might appreciate this I think if
you have a training where you are not
actually typing code and showing people
how it actually feels and looks like to
write the code in an editor
if all you have is slideware and and
things and animations and things I think
you're doing it wrong I think you need
to actually show an editor you need to
show you writing in code in order for it
to sink in a bit more I agree with that
100 like in almost everything you can
teach
like just to sort of back that up when
students learn about like algorithms in
school I feel like half the reason they
don't really understand them is because
they're often not seeing code and
they're not like using it extensively so
like they might see a couple blips of
code on the screen or something but they
don't actually like walk through like
let's actually write a binary search
from the ground up and see how it works
I can say from school I had so many
classmates who just if you ask them to
write a binary search they could explain
it to you but they could not code it for
some reason so there was some disconnect
there and then I did programming team so
I had to code this type of stuff like
all the time the programming team is
like top coder or like Google code Jam
that type of stuff is what we did all
the time I got to work with other people
who were very good at like breaking it
down and showing you like here's 10
examples of action coding this thing and
by the end you felt like you understood
the algorithms so much better than like
the idea of it being explained to you
like I feel like that's true for pretty
much anything you're teaching
programming wise if you can really
illustrate you know here's how you code
it I think that really helps it sink in
and especially people code along and try
to do it on their own because I think
that's another mistake people make like
they won't put in the time of actually
trying to do it themselves to see what
it feels like for themselves to code it
[Music]
